summary: This document is a compilation of news clips from January 13, 2020, focusing on the fallout from Jeffrey Epstein's connections to MIT and Silicon Valley. It summarizes multiple articles discussing an MIT-commissioned report on Epstein's donations and interactions with the university, as well as related stories about figures like Bill Gates, Reid Hoffman, and a lawsuit by Lawrence Lessig against The New York Times.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the scandal; his donations to MIT and interactions with Silicon Valley figures are the subject of the news reports and the MIT investigation.

persons.name: Bill Gates
persons.context: Discussed for his ties to Epstein, including meetings and a disputed $2 million donation to the MIT Media Lab that Epstein allegedly directed.

persons.name: Reid Hoffman
persons.role: LinkedIn founder, MIT Media Lab advisory board member
persons.context: Apologized for participating in fundraising with Epstein; brought Epstein to a 2015 dinner with tech leaders and was consulted on Epstein's involvement with MIT events.

persons.name: Joi Ito
persons.role: Former director of the MIT Media Lab
persons.context: Resigned after reports he concealed donations from Epstein; sought advice from Reid Hoffman about Epstein's involvement.

persons.name: Seth Lloyd
persons.role: Nam Pyo Suh Professor of Mechanical Engineering and Physics at MIT
persons.context: Placed on paid leave for failing to report personal and institutional donations from Epstein, including depositing $60,000 into a personal account.

persons.name: Rafael Reif
persons.context: Faced scrutiny over the Epstein donations; the MIT report found he did not know about the concealed donations, though he signed a gift acknowledgment in 2012.

persons.name: Lawrence Lessig
persons.context: Suing The New York Times for a story he claims falsely portrayed him as defending the solicitation of donations from Epstein.

persons.name: Alan G. Spoon
persons.context: Commented on the MIT report, expressing disturbance over Epstein's campus visits and expressing confidence in President Reif.

persons.name: Denis A. Bovin
persons.context: Commented on MIT's visitor policies and suggested using Epstein's status as a Level-3 sex offender as a guideline for restricting campus access.

persons.name: Israel Ruiz
persons.role: Former executive vice president and treasurer of MIT
persons.context: One of the vice presidents who knew about the Epstein donations and tried to cover them up; announced he is stepping down.

persons.name: Marvin Minsky
persons.context: Received a $100,000 donation from Epstein in 2002, according to the MIT report.

persons.name: Robert Millard
persons.context: Was reportedly targeted by Joi Ito in 2016 to woo Epstein as a donor; declined an invitation to dinner from Epstein.

persons.name: Leon Black
persons.context: Epstein reportedly claimed in 2014 to have arranged donations from him to MIT, which the MIT report found no evidence to support.

persons.name: Theodore Schleifer
persons.context: Author of the Recode article analyzing the MIT report and the ties between tech billionaires and Epstein.

persons.name: Colleen Flaherty
persons.context: Author of the Inside Higher Ed article on the fallout at MIT.

persons.name: Harper Neidig
persons.context: Author of The Hill article about Lawrence Lessig's lawsuit against The New York Times.

persons.name: Ronan Farrow
persons.context: Reported on Epstein's involvement in directing Bill Gates's donation to the MIT Media Lab.

connections.description: Epstein claimed to have arranged a $2 million donation from Gates to the MIT Media Lab in 2014; they had multiple private meetings.
Hoffman participated in fundraising activities with Epstein for the MIT Media Lab and brought him to a 2015 dinner with tech leaders.
Ito concealed donations from Epstein to the MIT Media Lab and sought his advice on involving Epstein in events.
Lloyd received $60,000 from Epstein personally and facilitated larger donations to MIT from him without proper reporting.
Hoffman was on the Media Lab advisory board; Ito consulted Hoffman in 2016 about whether to allow Epstein to attend a conference.
Ito tried to get Millard, chair of the MIT Corporation, to woo Epstein as a donor in 2016.

events.title: Disputed Gates Donation to MIT Media Lab
events.description: Epstein claimed to have arranged an anonymous $2 million donation from Bill Gates to the MIT Media Lab. Gates's representatives deny Epstein's involvement.

events.title: Epstein Dinner in Palo Alto
events.description: Reid Hoffman brought Jeffrey Epstein to a dinner in Palo Alto attended by prominent tech figures including Mark Zuckerberg, Elon Musk, and Peter Thiel.

events.title: Epstein Visits MIT Campus
events.description: Epstein visited the MIT campus to meet with Reid Hoffman and others, one of nine campus visits since 2013 noted in the MIT report.

events.title: Ito Consults Hoffman on Epstein
events.description: Joi Ito sought advice from Reid Hoffman about whether to allow Epstein to attend a conference with many people who might recognize him.

events.title: MIT Report Release and Fallout
events.description: MIT releases an external report by Goodwin Procter detailing Epstein's donations and interactions. Seth Lloyd is placed on leave, and MIT pledges to donate $850,000 to abuse survivors.

events.title: Lawrence Lessig Files Lawsuit Against NYT
events.description: Harvard law professor Lawrence Lessig sues The New York Times, claiming a story falsely portrayed him as defending the solicitation of donations from Jeffrey Epstein.

locations: U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts
keyFacts: An MIT-commissioned report found Jeffrey Epstein made donations totaling $850,000 to MIT, with $525,000 to the Media Lab and $225,000 to professor Seth Lloyd.
MIT professor Seth Lloyd was placed on paid leave for deliberately failing to report donations from Epstein, including $60,000 he deposited into a personal account.
The report detailed that Epstein visited MIT's campus nine times since 2013, which MIT Corporation members found 'very disturbing.'
Bill Gates's ties to Epstein were scrutinized, with internal MIT records suggesting Epstein 'directed' a $2 million Gates donation in 2014, which Gates denies.
Reid Hoffman apologized for his interactions with Epstein, which included a 2015 dinner in Palo Alto with tech leaders and fundraising activities for the MIT Media Lab.
